One reason why the "Big Dig" was plagued with so many cost overruns is because the engineers didn't anticipate the amount of sand on top of the proposed tunnels. That required very expensive temporary supports to prevent Beantown from collapsing during construction. The fact that unscrupulous construction firms skimped on the quality of the supports for the tunnel doesn't mean that the project was a bad idea and should have been scrapped entirely.

Tunneling between New York and New Jersey, though, is as easy as 1-2-3. Underground is solid rock, and the deeper one goes, one can dynamite or cut through with a tunnel boring machine without difficulty. And if not for a certain individual who shares your surname, Diana, we would have had such a tunnel decades ago.

One more thing in response to this:

"Your statement ... seems to negate your previous tolerance for inconsistent logical systems."

I mentioned the paraconsistent logic wiki page as a curiosity. If it has any real relevance to this problem, I wouldn't know, because I don't know anything about it. At no point did I promote this as a solution, or show tolerance for inconsistent logical systems. Throughout this discussion, I have always assumed that an inconsistent logical system cannot be used to draw valid conclusions. My contention from the beginning was that the student's error was in trying to use an inconsistent system to draw conclusions.

I dont know what the solution is, however, if someone breaks into your house, you have a right to defend yourself and your family. Everyone would agree to that. However, these are split second decisions. The people being violated shouldnt have to carry the burden of deciding correctly. The sumbags breaking in lose all their rights the second they break into someones home. The world is a better place without them. I would never kill someone stealing my TV, but in the heat of the moment, mistakes happen.
Worse, people's "feeling safer" is not much correlated with the facts about whether they are safer.  I suspect it's more highly correlated with actual fear than with actual safety.

The interpretation of the first amendment is more straightforward than that of the second amendment.  There are no apparent conflicts between different parts of the sentences in the first amendment.  Whatever else you think, that is a source of unclarity in the meaning, which has to be resolved by harder thinking and maybe historical knowledge.

Hopefully the military will never go against its own people.  However, that is precisely what the framers of the constitution had in mind when they enshrined the second amendment.  Assuming that Americans are still free and brave, there would not be much left for the military to govern, if the military tried it, right....

At least 26 States under the tutelage of Conservative Governors and Legislators, as per US SC conservative republican domination and this States Rights Hog was, has one or another similar laws.

All basically promoting use and or possession of guns ( bear arms ) any where from Churches, Bars, Restaurants to out houses. At least in a outhouse, one with pants down may wind up encountering a snake. Gun may come in handy, unless one shoots him or her self in the foot or some place else. But knowing these conservative republicans they are liable to run from the outhouse and with their pants around the ankles fall flat on their faces.

Or just imagine, some body just shoots up a outhouse or a preacher with a bad disposition. There have a case , where a right wing nut In Brookfield Wis. killed some seven in a church setting.

After a couple of cases where one or two Judges were shot while on the bench. Now at least in the South, a lot of them pack a six shooter under the black robes. Despite two armed Sheriff Deputies in the court room. Now there is a real place when the Judge can "stand his or her ground". In fact in a criminal case here in GA a Judge actually pulled a gun from under his robes, and showed a women in a domestic violence case what she should have done.

"It takes lots of practice (and money) to be lethal with a 1-3 pound gun."

If only this were true.

In fact, the only practice that is required is "aim and pull the trigger".

Those are good reasons to do something about both issues. I mean, you may expect government to impose regulations on more than one topic. You may certainly expect that from your politicians when so many people get killed by guns and motor vehicles.

Your first point does not negates the need for stricter rules on the latter. It just shows how high the risks are. To make your point even more clear you might want to compare these numbers with other countries. I mean how many people get killed with fire arms in Canada, The Netherlands, Germany, Japan, France etc. etc. on annual basis?

Fatalities from auto accidents are terrible,and maybe there should be longer permit time required before an actual license is given, but most people don't get in their cars with the purpose of injuring or killing themselves or killing someone else. When you purposely point a gun and pull a trigger you're aiming to inflict serious injury or death. I think you're comparing apples to oranges.

Fran Donovan

Approximately 16,000 homicides by firearm occur in the USA annually. Approximately 41,000 deaths occur by motor vehicle.

You must be 21 to legally own a handgun, and must pass an FBI background check.
You can legally drive a car in some states when you are 15 years old.

It takes lots of practice (and money) to be lethal with a 1-3 pound gun.
It takes very little experience to kill someone with a 1-3 ton vehicle.

Go figure.

comments.commentBody: Duke, I think a lot of us who aren't on the fringes one way or another could come together around something like this. Personally, I don't like guns and don't own one, but if reasonable controls are in place, I don't think I have any right to say whether you do. I just don't want to worry about trigger-happy idiots flashing their hardware around the streets when I'm headed out to buy a half gallon of milk.
The murder rate in Europe is about the same. They just use other means to accomplish the task.

In Texas a person licensed to carry a gun, driving in an automobile/pick-up truck, meeting an on-coming car in the opposite/left lane, fearing for his life that the on-coming car is about to harm him --- Is it legal for the gun carrier to shoot and kill the driver of the on-coming car, before the approacing car reaches his proximity or afterwards?

But, if a law is broken involving a shooting, the person who has been victimized is quite possibly dead, and thus can't testify. So the shooter can say whatever they like without fear of contradiction.  Seems like a good incentive for the aggressor to make sure their victim dies during the crime.

Yeah, not sure I'd go quite that far.  There is a real thing called self-defense, although I believe the burden of proof should lie with the shooter.  Since, in many cases, the shooter is the only one who can testify about anything.
Cool story bro. For every instance of self-defense with a gun, dozens more are killed by accident or intentionally.

How many of those writing today in the hope that gun control could actually become a reality in this country are now pounding on the doors of their political representative demanding a change? The NRA will not change. The GOP cannot change. It is up to the people. Remember this in November.

I have no doubt that there are some excellent uses of a gun for self-defense. The question is a question of quantity: How many times per year is a gun used legitimately for self-defense, versus tragically? Research and media seem to indicate there's infinitely more of the latter than the former. An individual must weigh the risks and benefits of gun ownership and carrying for him/herself, and society must do the same. It seems to be in the best interest of saving lives to be a little more careful than we are about who can get and carry lethal weapons. Also I don't understand why self-defense stories wouldn't make news. It's one thing to claim a liberal media bias-- ok, let's say the New York Times wouldn't report those stories. But there's a lot of red states, with high gun ownership rates, and the papers gun owners read, plus Fox news, and self-defense stories would help those papers entice readers, no? So why are there far more tragic than happy gun stories in the news, then?

Kyle, the 2nd was written when there was no regular standing army. Militias made up of private citizens were the country's defense. Those private citizens had to have firearms to function as the country's defense.

We don't have that situation any longer. Of course that doesn't mean we should outlaw firearms, but sensible licensing and regulation would make the country safer for everyone.

Ok but somehow no other industrialized nation has legions of helpless women and old people being shot in the streets, or killed in some other way, and gun ownership is much lower in those nations. We do not have more crime than other first world countries-- except for homicide, and much of that is gang-related. People are NOT shot by strangers-- they are shot by acquaintences/rivals. Or if you're female, by current or former boyfriends. There's plenty of research to back this up.

I have a problem with outside organizations writing laws for the folks we elected to do the writing. I like my guns too but it is just unamerican to do what they have done in Wisconsin and shame on those legislatures that allowed it. I am sure we will be reading about this state like we are with Florida.
Why not?  I can't think of a better way to force some sense into Florida politics than to have the tourist industry implode.

They lobby conservative lawmakers, and then the conservative lawmakers pass these outrageous laws. if you want things to change vote out the conservatives. I too look forward to the day the NRA no longer exists, I'm just afraid it won't be in my lifetime.

Fran Donovan

I will celebrate the day the NRA no longer exists. They serve no useful public service. They have to sneak laws through state legislatures in the dark of night because they know that what they do would never withstand the scrutiny of the full light of day.  Their constant petty attacks aimed at expanding gun rights are a microcosm of the kind self-centered petty politics that has polarized the political process in this country.

The real issue is burden of proof. I'm all for protecting yourself, or someone else, if shooting is the only option.  But if one party is dead, and the shooter is not required to say anything other than "I was really scared", just about anybody can kill just about anybody else, and if they are clever and tough enough, just walk away from it.
Violent crime has been going down in all the first world countries, not just the United States.  Nobody knows why for sure, but it's a stretch to assume it's because everybody is packing.

Not so fast. The fact that you had a problem with this person could also be used as a reason why you felt threatened in his or her presence.  In any event, the state is forced to fund an investigation to prove that you didn't have just cause (and proving that you had motive and intent is harder than you assert), rather than having the shooter prove that they did.  Burden of proof is in the wrong place.
